body_html:
I'm running TF commit 90df8ab (master as of yesterday from a few days ago). On Ubuntu 17.10. Built with bazel 0.11.1, gcc 6.4, nvcc 9.1 and cuda 9.1. Relevant bazel build options are -c opt --config=cuda (ie. -march=native).

However the behaviour I'm talking about is just part of the Dataset.list_files() kernel.

I hacked together a little script to demonstrate the behaviour. Some results on different disks I have here. All run with --width 100000:

  1. tmpfs:
load data: time: 4566.47 ms
prep data: time: 14.50 ms
read first filename: time: 14691.77 ms
read second filename: time: 0.36 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7742.66 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
  1. SSD (Samsung SM951 256GB SSD):
load data: time: 9190.51 ms
prep data: time: 19.00 ms
read first filename: time: 20781.54 ms
read second filename: time: 0.28 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7919.55 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
  1. External HDD (Samsung D3 Station, 4TB):
load data: time: 64532.58 ms
prep data: time: 18.13 ms
read first filename: time: 86195.52 ms
read second filename: time: 0.36 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7742.11 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
  1. External HDD (Seagate Expansion Desk 5TB):
load data: time: 119427.41 ms
prep data: time: 14.98 ms
read first filename: time: 77205.09 ms
read second filename: time: 0.33 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7723.63 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)

Note I'm not flushing caches at any point. Ok so the external drives are terrible, but as a realistic example, consider 1m files sitting on tmpfs:

load data: time: 48649.91 ms
prep data: time: 14.79 ms
read first filename: time: 315815.76 ms
read second filename: time: 0.43 ms
read 999998 more filenames: time: 86427.00 ms (0.09 ms per iteration)

That's still 5 minutes waiting before training starts.

I suppose I've got a feature request rather than a bug. It might be something I'll fix if no-one else is currently looking at it and the options suggested in the OP seem reasonable.

body:
I'm running TF commit 90df8ab4ab127fac239597ce0708577a335613bf (master ~~as of yesterday~~ from a few days ago). On Ubuntu 17.10. Built with bazel 0.11.1, gcc 6.4, nvcc 9.1 and cuda 9.1. Relevant bazel build options are `-c opt --config=cuda` (ie. -march=native).

However the behaviour I'm talking about is just part of the [`Dataset.list_files()` kernel](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/kernels/matching_files_op.cc#L46).

I hacked together a [little script](https://gist.github.com/darrengarvey/ff05fbe28ab2061c101fe64353b467ff) to demonstrate the behaviour. Some results on different disks I have here. All run with `--width 100000`:

1) tmpfs:
```
load data: time: 4566.47 ms
prep data: time: 14.50 ms
read first filename: time: 14691.77 ms
read second filename: time: 0.36 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7742.66 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
```
2) SSD (Samsung SM951 256GB SSD):
```
load data: time: 9190.51 ms
prep data: time: 19.00 ms
read first filename: time: 20781.54 ms
read second filename: time: 0.28 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7919.55 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
```

3) External HDD (Samsung D3 Station, 4TB):
```
load data: time: 64532.58 ms
prep data: time: 18.13 ms
read first filename: time: 86195.52 ms
read second filename: time: 0.36 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7742.11 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
```

4) External HDD (Seagate Expansion Desk 5TB):
```
load data: time: 119427.41 ms
prep data: time: 14.98 ms
read first filename: time: 77205.09 ms
read second filename: time: 0.33 ms
read 99998 more filenames: time: 7723.63 ms (0.08 ms per iteration)
```

Note I'm not flushing caches at any point. Ok so the external drives are terrible, but as a realistic example, consider 1m files sitting on tmpfs:

```
load data: time: 48649.91 ms
prep data: time: 14.79 ms
read first filename: time: 315815.76 ms
read second filename: time: 0.43 ms
read 999998 more filenames: time: 86427.00 ms (0.09 ms per iteration)
```
That's still 5 minutes waiting before training starts.

I suppose I've got a feature request rather than a bug. It might be something I'll fix if no-one else is currently looking at it and the options suggested in the OP seem reasonable.
